    Sanction dates

    sanction-dates.Rmd

    Packages:

    library(dopingdata)
library(dplyr)
library(tidyr)
library(stringr)
library(forcats)
library(lubridate)
library(readr)
library(readxl)
library(janitor)
library(anytime)

    Motivation

    This vignette covers how format and wrangle the sanction dates in the USADA sanctions table.

    Outline

    This vignette assumes the following:

    1. Scrape the website: A copy of the USADA sanctions table has been scraped and lives in the inst/extdata/raw/ folder

    • See vignettes/scraping-usada-sanctions.Rmd for more information

    • The raw sanction data is in the inst/extdata/raw folder:

      #> ../inst/extdata/raw/
#> â”œâ”€â”€ 2023-01-21_usada_sanctions_raw.csv
#> â””â”€â”€ 2023-01-22_usada_sanctions_raw.csv

    • The processed data have had all the column names formatted with janitor::clean_names(), and all the text has been converted to lowercase

    ```
#> â€©[01;34m../inst/extdata/â€©[0m
#> â””â”€â”€ usada_sanctions_pro.csv
```

    Data versioning

    This package uses data from a table that gets updated regularly. To keep track of the versions, Iâ€™ve organized the _raw and _pro data in the inst/extdata/ folder

    #> ../inst/extdata/raw/
#> â”œâ”€â”€ 2023-01-21_usada_prohib_assoc_raw.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ 2023-01-21_usada_sanctions_raw.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ 2023-01-22_usada_prohib_assoc_raw.csv
#> â””â”€â”€ 2023-01-22_usada_sanctions_raw.csv
    #> ../inst/extdata/
#> â”œâ”€â”€ substance_types.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ tidy_multp_aaf_subs.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ tidy_single_aafs.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ tidy_sports.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ usada_dates.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ usada_prohib_assoc_pro.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ usada_sanction_types.csv
#> â”œâ”€â”€ usada_sanctions_pro.csv
#> â””â”€â”€ usada_substance_types.csv

    I also have two helper functions for telling me the recent version:

    get_recent("../inst/extdata/")
âœ” The last modified date in '../inst/extdata/': 2023-01-23
       dstmp 
"2023-01-23" 
    get_recent_file("../inst/extdata/")
File last modified: 2023-01-22 18:43:39
âœ” import code pasted to clipboard!
[1] "../inst/extdata/usada_sanctions_pro.csv"

    These are handy whenever I need to find the most recently modified file in a folder!

    Import recent data file

    I can paste the import code from above to quickly import the most recent usada_sanctions_pro.csv data:

    usada_sanctions_pro <- readr::read_csv(
                          file = '../inst/extdata/usada_sanctions_pro.csv')
#> Rows: 895 Columns: 5
#> â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€

    Sanction dates

    I need to format the dates in sanction_announced as an actual date, but should check to see if theyâ€™re all in the same format.

    dplyr::mutate(usada_sanctions_pro, 
  sanction_announced = lubridate::mdy(sanction_announced)) |>

    Which ones failed? Store these in bad_dates.

    bad_dates <- mutate(usada_sanctions_pro, 
  sanction_date = lubridate::mdy(sanction_announced)) |> 
  dplyr::filter(is.na(sanction_date) & !is.na(sanction_announced)) 
#> Warning: 29 failed to parse.
bad_dates |> 
  dplyr::select(sanction_announced) |> 
  head(10)
#> # A tibble: 10 Ã— 1
#>    sanction_announced                       
#>    <chr>                                    
#>  1 original: 05/07/2019; updated: 02/04/2022
#>  2 original: 09/03/21; updated: 01/25/22    
#>  3 original:  11/04/2019;updated: 05/17/2021
#>  4 original 12/20/2018; updated 11/04/2020  
#>  5 original: 10/19/2020updated: 01/05/2021  
#>  6 original: 09/05/2019; updated: 08/26/2020
#>  7 original: 07/22/2020, updated: 11/03/2022
#>  8 original 09/11/2018; updated 01/16/2020  
#>  9 original: 06/17/2019; updated: 12/16/2019
#> 10 original: 10/31/2017; updated: 12/16/2019

    I can see theyâ€™ve stuffed two dates in the sanction_announced column for 29 athletes:

    1. I will use tidyr::separate_rows() to split the dates into original and updated
    2. Remove the excess colons and white-space with stringr::str_remove_all()
    3. filter out the original dates (I only want the updated date)
    4. convert the dates to date with anytime::anydate()
    5. take care of the single outlier (formatted with a two-year date)
    6. remove the sanction_announced column (use sanction_date instead)
    good_dates <- tidyr::separate_rows(data = bad_dates,
  sanction_announced, sep = "updated") |>
  dplyr::mutate(sanction_date = stringr::str_remove_all(sanction_announced, ": ")) |>
  dplyr::filter(!stringr::str_detect(sanction_date, "^original")) |>
  dplyr::mutate(sanction_date = anytime::anydate(sanction_date)) |>
  dplyr::mutate(
    sanction_date = dplyr::case_when(
      athlete == "ngetich, eliud" ~ lubridate::as_date("2022-01-25"),
      TRUE ~ sanction_date
    )
  ) |>
  dplyr::select(-sanction_announced)
good_dates |> glimpse()
#> Rows: 29
#> Columns: 5
#> $ athlete          <chr> "prempeh, ernest", "ngetich, eliud", "gehm, zach", "hâ€¦
#> $ sport            <chr> "weightlifting", "track and field", "track and field"â€¦
#> $ substance_reason <chr> "dhcmt, androgenic anabolic steroids; non-analytical:â€¦
#> $ sanction_terms   <chr> "4-year suspension; loss of results; sanction tolled â€¦
#> $ sanction_date    <date> 2022-02-04, 2022-01-25, 2021-05-17, 2020-11-04, 2021â€¦

    Now I want to format the dates in usada_sanctions_pro using anytime::anydate(), then filter out the missing sanction_dates that didnâ€™t parse, remove the sanction_announced column, and bind this back to the good_dates table with fixed sanction dates.

    usada_dates <- dplyr::mutate(usada_sanctions_pro, 
    sanction_date = anytime::anydate(sanction_announced)) |> 
  dplyr::filter(!is.na(sanction_date)) |> 
  dplyr::select(-sanction_announced) |> 
  dplyr::bind_rows(good_dates) 
dplyr::glimpse(usada_dates)
#> Rows: 658
#> Columns: 5
#> $ athlete          <chr> "montaÃ±ez barroso, elias", "ruiz-gutierrez, noslen", â€¦
#> $ sport            <chr> "cycling", "cycling", "track and field", "cycling", "â€¦
#> $ substance_reason <chr> "non-analytical: refusal to submit to sample collectiâ€¦
#> $ sanction_terms   <chr> "4-year suspension; loss of results", "4-year suspensâ€¦
#> $ sanction_date    <date> 2023-01-10, 2023-01-04, 2022-12-08, 2022-12-05, 2022â€¦

    Export

    Export the usada_dates to inst/extdata/

    export_extdata(
  x = usada_dates, 
  inst_path = "../inst/", 
  raw = FALSE)
#> â„¹ Exporting data: usada_dates
#> âœ” Exporting data: usada_dates ... done
#> 
#> âœ” Data successfully exported!

    Verify

    fs::dir_tree("../inst/extdata/", regexp = "dates")
#> ../inst/extdata/
#> â””â”€â”€ usada_dates.csv
